Correction: Only eDiscovery Administrators can remove members from a case.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/ediscovery-add-or-remove-members-from-a-case

Both eDiscovery Admin and eDiscovery Manager have the same permissions; the only difference is that Administrator have access to ALL Cases, while Managers have access to ONLY the case they are part of.

The link you provided is contradicting itself, if I am reading it correctly. Under eDiscovery Administrator it states 'Remove members from an eDiscovery case. So, I am not sure on the first statement, I agree with the other 2

discussion.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/ediscovery-assign-permissions
It should be Yes - No - Yes. 

eDiscovery Manager - An eDiscovery Manager can use eDiscovery search tools to search content locations in the organization, and perform various search-related actions such as preview and export search results. Members can also create and manage cases in Microsoft Purview eDiscovery (Standard) and Microsoft Purview eDiscovery (Premium), add and remove members to a case, create case holds, run searches associated with a case, and access case data. eDiscovery Managers can only access and manage the cases they create. They can't access or manage cases created by other eDiscovery Managers.

For part two of the question. Answer is Admin 1 only

To view the Permissions tab you need to be an admin. Specifically, you need to be assigned the Role Management role, and that role is assigned only to the Organization Management and Purview Administrators role groups by default. The Role Management role also allows you to view, create, and modify role groups.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-office-365/scc-permissions#role-groups-in-microsoft-defender-for-office-365-and-microsoft-purview

Admin1, Admin2 and User4 only
Admin1 and Admin2 only

There is some ambuiguity in the documentation of MS.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/compliance-manager-setup#role-types => says that Compliance Manager Contributor can edit and create, but Compliance Manager Assesor can only "edit but can't create". 
But https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/compliance-manager-assessments#create-assessments => this document says "Only users who hold a Global Administrator, Compliance Manager Administration, or Compliance Manager Assessor role can create and modify assessments" . 
The answers change based on which document you follow.

Both are correct.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains two groups named Group1 and Group2.

You have the compliance assessments shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You have the improvement actions shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You perform the following actions:

â€¢ Create and publish a retention label.
â€¢ Implement security awareness training for all users.
â€¢ For Action4, change Implementation status to Implemented.

For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: I think it should be Y Y Y

comments.content:
CoPilot:
Operational Action Types, like Action4 and Action5, typically require a status change to "Implemented" in order to update the compliance scores. This is because operational actions often involve procedural or policy changes that need to be confirmed as completed before they can be considered effective.

In your case, for the compliance scores to be updated:

Action4 (Restrict Access to privileged accounts) associated with CA1 needs to have its status set to "Implemented".
Action5 (Update security awareness training) associated with CA2 also needs to have its status set to "Implemented".
Once these actions are marked as implemented, the compliance scores for the respective assessments should be updated accordingly. It's important to ensure that the implementation status is accurately reflected in your compliance management system to maintain the integrity of the compliance scores.

discussion.content:
It Should be YNN
Technical Actions Updates Scores automaticly
Operational Updates Scores only on Status Updates

CA1 Action1 5 Points + Action4(Status Implemented) 10 Points = 15 Points
CA2 Action2 5 Points = 5 Points (Action5 are Implemented but Status wasnÂ´t Updated)
CA3 0 Points (Action6 are Implemented but Status wasnÂ´t Updated)

I believe All Y

As per the link
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/compliance-manager-improvement-actions#improvement-actions-page
Points achieved
There is no difference between technical and operational, it is just type.

I think it should be Y-Y-N and the difference is made from the action for that is implemented. action5 and action6 are not implemented. from this link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/compliance-manager-improvement-actions I read " When an improvement action is successfully tested and implemented, you receive the maximum possible points for that action, which gets credited to your overall compliance score."
so, the action has to be implemented to be counted

Points are awarded per action per assessment. For example, if an action is worth 10 points but it appears in two assessments, the action is worth 20 points overall for your tenant. An exception is for technical actions that are scoped to your tenant; points for these actions are granted once per action, regardless of how many groups the action belongs to.

The answer should be Y-Y-Y. 
1. 5 points increase for label and 10 points for privileged account restriction
2. 5 points for label and 10 points for training
3. 10 points for training

comments.content: Your explanation is correct, the answer should be Y-Y-Y

"Technical improvment actinons are per tenant, not per group" , this statement is correct but your understanding of it is not correct. Basically, lets say there are 2 improvement actions "Do xyz" in assessment 1 and assessment 2, each worth 10 points. Then if you implement both of them then 10 points gets increased to each assessment and 20 points gets increased to tenant. But if that improvement action is "technical", then for tenant it will be only counted once, so only 10 points increased for tenant score but each assessment will also get 10 point increase..

discussion.content:
In my opinion this is correct.
Technical improvment actinons are per tenant, not per group. In result, scoring per group has not been increased. Operational actions are calculated per group, but increase only +10 points. So only C23 increase +10 (N, N, Y)

I think it should be Yes, No, No... 

It mentions specifically that you change the implementation status of Action 4. However, it does not mention changing the status of Action Items 5 and 6. Even though the training was completed it will not update the score until the status is changed as I don't believe MS has a way of tracking the training for all users it's self reported. 

So CA1 will increase through the actions taken by 15 Points. 
5 for the retention Label
10 for Action 4 being set to implemented

CA 2 will increase by 5 points for the Retention Label, but will not increase for the training as it has not been set to implemented

CA3 will increase by 0 points as the Training has not be set to implemented and the Win10 baseline has not been enabled.
The answer is correct as it is N-N-Y, because scoring is 25-25-10

comments.content:
Agree, The overall compliance score is calculated using action scores, where each Microsoft action is counted once, each technical action you manage is counted once, and each non-technical action you manage is counted once per group.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/compliance-manager-scoring
Confusing question; perhaps it's Y N N (15-10-15)

HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription. Auditing is enabled.

A user named User1 is a member of a dynamic security group named Group1.

You discover that User1 is no longer a member of Group1.

You need to search the audit log to identify why User1 was removed from Group1.

Which two activities should you use in the search? To answer, select the appropriate activities in the answer area.

//IMG//

discussion.content: Updated user and uptaded group?

Got the time and testet it:
Answer is:
- Updated group => shows what user 'updated' the group.
- Removed member from group => shows the user that was removed (by modifying dynamic the query)

This is wrong, you cant manually add/remove a user from a dynamic group. If the user has been removed from the group, the query no longer matches their account, so either the user has been updated or the group has been updated. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/users/groups-dynamic-membership
